page.title: 14Burringham River Bank.
page.content: The river has long bends in it and there are smooth patches where there were small whirlpools. It is a murky, grey/black river with some oil on the surface. The banks were muddy and wet because the water had been in and now it was going out. The Trent flows into the Humber Estuary and then into the North Sea. Sometimes the river nearly floods the village and almost comes over the top of the 2m. high bank that has been added to the river bank to stop flooding. We saw an empty barge going up the river, perhaps it was going to Gainsborough. On the bank were the remains of the stone railway bridge which used to cross the Trent here. Rusty old iron railway tracks poked out from the bank and we could follow the embankment back down the side of the school to where it joins the new railway line from Scunthorpe.
